etymologies: 1950s; earliest use found in Arthur Grollman (b. 1901). Apparently from meth- + -anthe- + -l- (in systematic name of compound, or perhaps simply epenthetic) + -ine

definitions: More fully "methantheline bromide". An anticholinergic drug used to treat peptic ulcer, hyperhidrosis, and bladder spasm; N,N- diethyl-N-methyl-2-[(9H-xanthen-9-ylcarbonyl)oxy]ethanaminium bromide, C₂₁ H₂₆ BrNO₃.

notes.text: International Nonproprietary Name (1996) and British Approved Name (1997): methanthelinium bromide.
